newsitem.title: DENMARK: Danish bond prices modestly down in jittery market.
newsitem.headline: Danish bond prices modestly down in jittery market.

text.p: Danish bond prices were only moderately down in jittery trade on Tuesday after the Wall Street decline, with investors taking refuge in short-term paper but the market was seen stabilising at present levels.
"The Danish market has done better than Germany and we should stabilise. There has been no panic but long-term jitters are sending investors into short-term paper," one dealer said.

The benchmark eight percent state bond due 2006 was down 0.59 point from Friday's close but 0.01 up on the opening at 108.01 at 1130 gmt, with the 10-year yield gap with Germany three basis points narrower than at the start at 77.
Dealers said they expected a relatively quiet afternoon with the U.S. March NAPM amd February leading indicators not seen having any great influence.
The 2006 benchmark yielded 6.77 percent in turnover of 1.6 billion crowns while the six percent mortgage bond due 2026 lost 0.35 point to 86.40.
The crown traded at 3.8100 per mark at 1135 gmt virtually unchanged compared to 3.8105 at the opening.
